correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

Page 2 SHORT FORM IT-200 1959
GENERAL INFORMATION
WHO MAY USE THE SHORT FORM IT-200
You may file on this Short Form IT-200 if you meet all of the
following requirements:
1. You were a resident of New York for the entire calendar
year 1959.
2. Your gross income (or, if married and living together,
the combined gross income of husband and wife) did
not exceed $10,000.
3. Your income was received solely from earnings as an
employee and from interest and dividends.
4. You (and your wife or husband if you are married and
filing separate returns) are claiming the optional deduc
tion of 10% of gross income, not to exceed $1000.
By Filing Your Return on Short Form IT-200, you hove
elected to hove your tax computed from the Tax Table
on the lost two pages of Instructions (Form IT-200-I or
1T-20I-P), which Table automatically allows deductions to
the extent of approximately 10% of your income.
If you are entitled to file a joint return with your wife
(husband) but you are not including her (his) income in
your return, you may file on Short Form IT-200 only if your
wife (husband) also files on Short Form IT-200.
NOTE: The return for a taxpayer who died during the year
and who was a New York resident at the time of his death
must be tiled on Form IT-206.
WHO MAY NOT USE THE SHORT FORM IT-200
You may not file on this Short Form IT-200 if:
( 1 jf!
1. You were not a resident of New York for the entire
year 1959.
2. You had gross income in excess of $10,000.
3. You and your wife (husband) had a combined gross
income in excess of $10,000.
4. You had income from any source other than earnings
as an employee, interest and dividends.
5. You had capital gains (or losses).
6. You are claiming itemized deductions instead of the
optional deduction.
7. You are entitled to file a joint return with your wife
(husband) and she (he) is filing a separate return on
Long Form IT-201.
8. You are claiming an exclusion from gross income for
sick pay.
9. You paid an estimated tax for 1959. (The filing of a
no-tax Declaration for 1959 does not disqualify you
from using Short Form IT-200.)
10. Your 1959 return discloses on overpayment and you
wish to have such overpayment credited and applied
to your I960 estimated tax.
11. You are filing on the basis of a fiscal period other
than a calendar year.
12. You are including in your return income of dependent
minor children.
IMPORTANT — File This Return At The District Office Listed Below For The County Where You Live

WHO MAY USE THE SHORT FORM IT-200
GENERAL INFORMATION
Ypu may file on fhis Short Form 11-200 If you meet all of the
following requirements:
1. You were a resident of New York for the entire calendar
year 1959.
2. Your gross income (or, if married and living together,
the combined gross income of husband and wife) did
not exceed $10,000.
Your income was received solely from earnings as an
' employee and from interest and dividends.
4. You (and your wife or husband if you are married and
{i t 10) filing separate returns) are claiming the optional deduc
tion of 10% of gross income, not to exceed $1000.
By Filing Your Return on Short Form IT-200, you hove
elected to have your tax computed from the Tax Table
on the last two pages of Instructions (Form 1T-200-I or
IT-201-P), which Table automatically allows deductions to
the extent of approximately 10% of your income.
If you are entitled to file a joint return with your wife
(husband) but you are not including her (his) income in
your return, you may file on Short Form 11-200 only if your
wife (husband) also files on Short Form IT-200.
NOTE: The return for a taxpayer who died during the year
and who was a New York resident at the time of his death
must be filed on Form IT-206.
WHO MAY NOT USE THE SHORT FORM IT-200
You may not file on this Short Form IT-200 if:
1. You were not a resident of New York for the entire
year 1959.
2. You had gross income in excess of $10,000.
3. You and your wife (husband) had a combined gross
income in excess of $10,000.
4. You had income from any source other than earnings
as an employee, interest and dividends.

rr-200 INSTRUCTIONS 1964
Card Form IT-200 Is lo ise used wifh the tax table which allows the standard 10% deduction. If you wish to Itemize your
deductions, use long formIT-201 orIT-208. You may itemize New York deductions only if you itemized deductions on your
Federal return. However, if you itemized deductions on your Federal return, you may itemize deductions or claim the standard
deduction on your State return.
Married persons who file a joint Federal return and wish to file separate New York State returns must use Form IT-208.
Card Form IT-200 is to be used only to report wages, interest and dividends of less than $10,000, not more than $1,000 of
which is from interest and dividends. The long form should be used if you (1) had income exceeding these amounts; or (2)
were a resident of New York for only part of the year 1964; or (3) made payments of estimated Income tax for 1964; or
(4) had any income exempt from Federal income tax but subject to New York State income tax.
You should file this return on or before April 15, 1965, at the New York State District Tax Office serving the county where
you live. Enclose with it copy numbered "1" of FormIT-2102 received from each employer.
If there is a balance of more than $1.00 of tax due shown at Line 9 on this return, please remit the full amount to "New York
State Income Tax Bureau." You need not remit a balance due of .$1.00 or less.
A refund of $1.00 or less will be issued only If requested.
See Instruction Sheet Form IT-200-I for the tax table, additional Instructions for this Card Form and locations of District
Tax Offices.

FORM IT-2105 (Page 2) NEW YORK STATE
DECLARATION OF ESTIMATED INCOME TAX INSTRUCTIONS
1965
1. PURPOSE OF DECLARATION — The Declaration provides a
means of paying your personal income tax on a current basis if you
have income from sources other than wages on which tax is withheld.
It is also used for paying unincorporated business income tax on a
current basis. Declarations of both estimated personal income tax
and estimated unincorporated business income tax may be made on
one Form IT-2105. Use name and address as shown on your personal
income tax return.
If you are entitled to a refund because the amount withheld from
your wages and/or the amount paid or credited as estimated tax
for the taxable year exceeds your actual tax liability, you must file
an income tax return to obtain the refund. See instructions for filing
personal income tax returns and unincorporated business tax returns
for full information including other filing requirements.
2. WHO MUST MAKE A DECLARATION — You must file a
Declaration if you expect your total New York income (as defined
in Instruction 3 below), other than from wages on which New
York State income tax is withheld, to exceed $600 multiplied by the
number of your exemptions, plus $400.
A Declaration must also be filed if you carry on an unincorporated
business within New York State and expect your unincorporated
business taxable income (Line 11 of Tax (Computation Schedule) to
exceed $2,500. Individuals, estates and trusts required to make Decla
rations of Estimated Unincorporated Business Tax must use Form
IT-2105; partnerships, joint ventures and other similar entities must
use Form IT-2105-UB.
Note: See Instructions 9 and 10 permitting a 1965 personal or unin
corporated business income tax return to be filed instead of
the Declaration otherwise required.
3. HOW TO ESTIMATE YOUR TAX FOR 1965 — The Tax Com
putation Schedule on the front of this form will help you estimate your
tax for 1965. Use 1964 income tax forms and instructions as a guide.
Personal Income Tax — The term "total New York income" (Line
1 of Tax Computation Schedule) means New. York Adjusted Gross
Income which is Federal Adjusted Gross Income as defined in the
Federal Internal Revenue Code, plus or minus the additions and sub
tractions described in the instructions for New York resident returns
(Forms IT-201-I and IT-201-P) and New York nonresident returns
(Forms IT-203-P and IT-203-I). The "total New York income" of a
nonresident relates only to items from New York sources. The term
"Estimated Tax" (Line 3 of Declaration) as applied to personal
income tax is the amount you estimate as your 1965 personal income
tax liability less the tax you expect to be withheld throughout the year.
Unincorporated Business Income Tax — The term "net income
from business" (Line 9 of Tax Computation Schedule) means the
amount you estimate to be your 1965 net income from business
computed according to the instructions for Line 1, Schedule U-C of
1964 Unincorporated Business Tax Return Form IT-202. The term
"Estimated Tax" (Line 3 of Declaration) as applied to unincorpo
rated business income tax is the amount you estimate as your 1965
unincorporated business income tax liability.
See Schedule U-C of 1964 Form IT-202 to determine Business Tax
Credit to be entered on Line 13 of Tax Computation Schedule.
4. PERSONAL INCOME TAX RATES —
New York Tax Rate Schedule
7. FISCAL YEAR TAXPAYERS — If you report income on a fiscal
year basis, substitute the corresponding fiscal year months for the
months specified in the various Instructions. For example, if your
fiscal year begins on April 1, 1965, your Declaration of Estimated
Income Tax will be due on July 15, 1965, together with payment of
first quarter estimated tax. In this instance, equal installments will
be due on or before September 15, 1965; December 15, 1965 and
April 15, 1966.
8. JOINT. DECLARATION — A husband and wife may file a joint
Declaration unless they are separated under a decree of divorce or
of separate maintenance, or have different taxable years. If a joint
Declaration is made but separate returns are filed for the taxable
year, the estimated tax for that year may be treated as the estimated
tax of either the husband or the wife, or it may be divided between
them as they see fit.
9. ESTIMATED TAX OF $40 OR LESS—If the estimated liability
for either personal income tax or unincorporated business income tax
is $40 or less, you may file your Declaration with respect to such
tax on or before January 15, 1966 instead of April 15, 1965. At that
• time, you must pay the entire balance of estimated tax. However,
if you file your 1965 tax return on or before February 15, 1966, and
pay the total tax with your return at that time, you need not file
a 1965 Declaration with respect to an estimated tax liability which
is $40 or less.
10. FARMERS — If at least two-thirds of your total New York
income for personal income tax purposes or your taxable income
for unincorporated business tax purposes is from farming you may file
the Declaration of such tax on or before January 15, 1966, instead
of April 15, 1965. At that time, you must pay the entire balance of.
estimated tax. However, if you file your 1965 tax return on or
before February 15, 1966, and pay the total tax with your return
at that time, you need not file a 1965 Declaration with respect to
such estimated tax.
11. CHANGES IN INCOME, EXEMPTIONS, ETC. — Even though
on April 15, 1965, you do not expect your income to be large enough
to require filing a Declaration, a change in income or exemptions
(or allocation in the case of a Declaration of Estimated Unincorpo
rated Business Income Tax) may require you to file a Declaration
later. In this event, the requirements are as follows:

If you file your 1965 tax return by February 15, 1966, and pay
the full balance of tax due, you need not: (a) file an amended
Declaration or an original Declaration otherwise due for the first
time on January 15, 1966, or (b) pay the last installment of estimated
tax otherwise due and payable on January 15, 1966.
Note: Filing a Declaration or an amended Declaration, or payment
of the last installment on January 15, 1966, or filing a tax
return by February 15, 1966, will hot satisfy the filing require
ments if you failed to file or pay an estimated tax which was
due earlier in your taxable year. (See, Instruction 13.)

RETURN OF NET CAPITAL GAIN SUBJECT TO NET CAPITAL GAIN TAX (1957)
SCHEDULE F.^AINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction F)
Include all property sold or exchsinged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business (which must be reported at Item 28 of Schedule A, page 3).
Losses through securities claimed to be worthless are to be reported here.
Each treinsaction must be computed separately. As to prof)erty acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or January
I, 1919 value, whichever is higher; in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
and January I, 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly Or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual return as partnership gain or loss.

(See Instruction F)
Include all property sold or exchanged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used m business (which must be reported at Item 28 of Schedule A, pag ).
Losses through securities claimed to he worthless are to be reported here.
Each transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gam, "se cost or January
I, 1919 value, whichever is higher; in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January I. 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
£ind January 1, 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc.. must be reported in the individual return as partnership gam or loss.

METHOD OF PAYMENT: Taxpayers may elect to pay
the total amount of Normal Tax and Net Capital Gain Tax
in full at the time the return is filed or in installments, pro
vided the total tax is more than $10. If such total tax is
$40. or more, the tax may be paid in four equal install
ments. If the tax is more than $10. and less than $40., no
installment may be less than $10. except the last. Install
ment due dates for the CALENDAR YEAR 1955 are:
(1) April 15, 1956; (2) July 15, 1956;
(3) November 15, 1956; (4) February 15, 1957.
For FISCAL YEARS, the due dates are:
(1) Due date for filing return; (2) 15th day of 3rd month;
(3) 15th day of 7th month; (4) 15th day of lOth month
after original due date for filing return.
The Unincorporated Business Tax MUST BE PAID IN
FULL at the time the return is filed.

METHOD OF PAYMENT; Taxpayers may elect to pay the aggregate amount of
Normal Tax and Net Capital Gain Tax in full at the time the return is filed or in in
stallments, provided the aggregate tax is MORE than $10.00. If such aggregate tax
i& ^0.00 or more, the tax may be paid in four equal installments. If the tax is more
tjian $10.00 and less than ^0.00, no installment may be less than $10.00 except the
last. The Unincorporated Business Tax MUST BE PAID IN FULL at the time the
return is filed. DO NOT MAIL CURRENCY.

SCHEDULE E. — GAINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction VII — Schedule E)
Include all property sold or exchanged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business (which must be reported at Item 28 of Schedule A, page 3).
Losses through securities claimed to be worthless are to be reported here.
Eiach transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or January
I. 1919 value, whichever is higher: in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
and January 1, 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual return as partnership gam or loss.

SCHEDULE E. — GAINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction VII — Schedule E)
Include all property sold or exchanged, except stock in tr-ade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business (which must be reported at Item 28 of Schedule A, page 3).
Losses through securities claimed to be worthless are to be reported here
Elach transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or Jemuary
1, 1919 value, whichever is higher: in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
and January 1, 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a pEu-tnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual retum as partnership gain or loss.

SCHEDULE E. — GAINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction VII — Schedule E)
Include all property sold or exchanged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business (which must be reported at Item 28 of Schedule A, page 3).
Losses through securities claimed to be worthless are to be reported here
Each transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or January
1, 1919 value, whichever is higher: in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
and January 1, 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual return as partnership gain or loss.

SCHEDULE E. — GAINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction VII — Schedule E)
Include all propertj' sold or exchanged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
, in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business. Losses througn securities claimed to be worthless are to be
' reported here.
Each transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January I , 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or January
i, 1919 value, whichever is higher; in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls Iretween cost
and January I , 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
i Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
: a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual return as partnership gain or loss.

SCHEDULE E. — GAINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction VII — Schedule E)
Include all property sold or exchanged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business. Losses through securities claimed to be worthless are to be
reported here.
Each transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or January
1, 1919 value,whichever is higher; in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
and January 1 , 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual return as partnership gain or loss.

RETURN OF NET CAPITAL GAIN SUBJECT TO NET CAPITAL GAIN TAX (1951)
SCHEDULE E. — GAINS AND LOSSES FROM SALES OR EXCHANGES OF STOCKS, BONDS, LANDS, BUILDINGS, AND OTHER PROPERTY
(See Instruction VII — Schedule E)
Include all property sold or exchanged, except stock in trade, or property includible in inventory, or property held primarily for sale to customers
in the ordinary course of trade or business, or land or depreciable property used in business. Losses through securities claimed to be worthless are to be
reported here.
Each transaction must be computed separately. As to property acquired prior to January 1, 1919, in the case of an actual gain, use cost or January
1, 1919 value,whichever is higher; in the case of an actual loss, use cost or January 1, 1919 value, whichever is lower; if the sales price falls between cost
Eind January 1, 1919 value, report neither gain nor loss.
Where the securities sold were owned jointly or in common with others or where an interest in a group, pool, syndicate, or joint venture was held,
a partnership return must be filed. The share of each such joint owner, etc., must be reported in the individual return as partnership gain or loss.
